notesStmt.p: Muspilli is an incomplete verse narrative (103 lines) written in Old High German. The manuscript containing the poem, which was produced in Bavaria (southern Germany) in the 9th century CE, contains neither the beginning nor the end of the poem. The reason for its incompleteness is probably due to its having been written in the margins of another text: a Latin theological work composed by Adalram (d. 836), bishop of Salzburg, for the young Louis the German (ca. 810–876). It appears Muspilli was added to the manuscript later by a different scribe, but little can be deduced about who produced the text or why. It is conjectured that the beginning and end have been lost because they would have been written on the outermost pages of the manuscript, which often incur the most damage over time.

One of the most debated questions about Muspilli is its name. The original manuscript does not include a title, and the name Muspilli was assigned by the poem's first editor, Johann Andreas Schmeller. The name comes from the Old High German word muspille, meaning the destruction of the world by fire, which occurs in line 57 of the poem. This is the only known occurrence of this word. Scholars have since tried to give it various names which better suit the purpose of the poem, but none of these has stuck.

Muspilli mainly deals with two main ideas: the fate of human souls after death and the Final Judgement. The first part of the poem describes how two groups of angels will fight over one soul to see whether it belongs in Heaven or Hell. The second part of the poem provides two narratives: Elijah and the Antichrist fight each other, the former as the champion of God and the latter as the champion of the Devil. In this duel, the Antichrist will be defeated and Elijah will be wounded and his blood will burn the whole world. Then the text describes how, in the Final Judgement, angels and demons will testify to the actions of humans on earth, and those actions will be scrutinized. At the end of the poem, the Holy Cross is brought forth and Christ reveals the wounds that he suffered for the sake of humankind.

One of the most discussed aspects of this poem are its sources. Although explicitly Christian elements are abundant, scholars have argued that Muspilli is deeply infused with pre-Christian culture and draws much of its material from Norse mythology. Although the names mentioned in the poem are all Christian figures, some scholars argue that they are essentially the Christian representation of Norse gods.

Muspilli is considered to be one of the most significant pieces of Old High German literature because of its vivid depiction of Christian themes in the vernacular language. Through this poem, modern readers can gain a better insight into the spiritual life and broader culture of ninth-century Germans.

Murdoch, Brian. “The Carolingian Period and the Early Middle Ages (750–1100).” The Cambridge History of German Literature, edited by Helen Watanabe-O'Kelly, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1997, pp. 1–39.
An overview of German literature from 750-1100 CE which includes discussion of Muspilli (on pp. 24).

An overview of Old High German verse texts, including a comparison between the Wessobrunn Prayer, Muspilli, and Lay of Ludwig (all published in the Global Medieval Sourcebook).

projectDesc.p: "Muspilli" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Muspilli
app.rdg: Muspilli

app.lem: ...sin tac piqueme, daz er touuan scal.
app.rdg: ...his day comes, when he has to die.

app.lem: uuanta sar so sih diu sela in den sind arhevit
app.rdg: Immediately afterwards, when the soul starts its journey

app.lem: enti si den lihhamun likkan lazzit,
app.rdg: and leaves the body behind,

app.lem: so quimit ein heri fona himilzungalon,
app.rdg: then a host comes from the heaven’s firmament

app.lem: daz andar fona pehhe: dar pagant siu umpi.
app.rdg: And another from hell: then they will fight for her [i. e. the soul].

app.lem: Sorgen mac diu sela, unzi diu suona arget,
app.rdg: The soul has to worry until the judgement is made,

app.lem: za uuederemo herie si gihalot uuerde.
app.rdg: As to which host she is brought.

app.lem: uuanta ipu sia daz Satanazses kisindi kiuuinnit,
app.rdg: For if Satan’s retainers win her,

app.lem: daz leitit sia sar dar iru leid uuirdit,
app.rdg: They promptly lead her [the soul] to a place where pain awaits her,

app.lem: in fuir enti in finstri: daz ist rehto uirinlih ding.
app.rdg: Into fire and darkness: that is a truly horrible verdict.

app.lem: Upi sia auar kihalont die, die dar fona himile quemant,
app.rdg: But if she is taken by those who come from heaven

app.lem: enti si dero engilo eigan uuirdit,
app.rdg: And is claimed by the angels,

app.lem: die pringent sia sar uf in himilo rihi:
app.rdg: They promptly bring her up into the heavenly kingdom

app.lem: dar ist lip ano tod, lioht ano finstri,
app.rdg: Where there is life without death, light without darkness,

app.lem: selida ano sorgun: dar nist neoman siuh.
app.rdg: A refuge without worry: there nobody suffers sickness.

app.lem: denne der man in pardisu pu kiuuinnit,
app.rdg: For if a person wins a place in paradise,

app.lem: hus in himile, dar quimit imo hilfa kinuok.
app.rdg: A house in heaven, he will find a lot of support there.

app.lem: Pidiu ist durft mihhil
app.rdg: Thus the need is great

app.lem: allero manno uuelihemo, daz in es sin muot kispane,
app.rdg:
for everybody, that his [spirit/heart]
The correct translation of “muot” is controversial. A large camp of scholars translate it as “spirit” ( “der Geist” in modern German), although others translate it as "heart". is moved

app.lem: daz er kotes uuillun kerno tuo
app.rdg: to gladly do God’s will

app.lem: enti hella fuir harto uuise,
app.rdg: And firmly avoid hellfire,

app.lem: pehhes pina. dar piutit Satanaz altist
app.rdg: Hell’s pain: there, the ancient Satan waits

app.lem: heizzan lauc. so mac huckan za diu,
app.rdg: With hot fire. Therefore he, who knows himself

app.lem: sorgen drato, der sih suntigen uueiz.
app.rdg: to be sinful, shall think about this with great worry.

app.lem: uue demo in uinstri scal sino uirina stuen,
app.rdg: Woe to him who has to atone for his sins in darkness

app.lem: prinnan in pehhe: daz ist rehto paluuic dink,
app.rdg: and burn in hell. It is a truly horrible judgement,

app.lem: daz der man haret ze gote enti imo hilfa ni quimit.
app.rdg: When somebody calls upon God and receives no help.

app.lem: uuanit sih kinada diu uuenaga sela.
app.rdg: The wretched soul hopes for mercy,

app.lem: ni ist in kihuctin himiliskin gote,
app.rdg: But she is not remembered by the heavenly God,

app.lem: uuanta hiar in uuerolti aftar ni uuerkota.
app.rdg: because she has not proven herself worthy here in the world.

app.lem: So denne der mahtigo khuninc daz mahal kipannit,
app.rdg: And when the powerful King proclaims the day of judgement

app.lem: dara scal queman queman chunno kilihaz.
app.rdg: Every kin must come there.

app.lem: denne ni kitar parno nohhein den pan furisizzan,
app.rdg: No child of man can dare to reject this command,

app.lem: nio allero manno uuelih ze demo mahale sculi.
app.rdg: [assuming] that not everybody had to attend this judgement.

app.lem: Dar scal er uora demo rihhe az rahhu stantan,
app.rdg:
There he shall give account to the Almighty
“rahha stantan” is a legal technical term meaning “to give an account for something.”. The expression is still used in modern German as “Rechenschaft stehen”.

app.lem: pi daz er in uuerolti kiuuerkot hapeta.
app.rdg: for what he has done in this world.

app.lem: daz hortih rahhon dia uueroltrehuuison,
app.rdg: I have heard the wise men of the world tell

app.lem: daz sculi der antichristo mil Eliase pagan.
app.rdg: That the antichrist shall fight against Elijah.

app.lem: der uuarch ist kiuuafanit, denne uuirdit untar in uuic arhapan.
app.rdg: The fiend is armed, and then the fight between them will start.

app.lem: khenfun sint so kreftic, diu kosa ist so mihhil:
app.rdg: The fighters are so powerful, the cause is so crucial:

app.lem: Elias stritit pi den ewiigon lip,
app.rdg: Elijah fights for eternal life,

app.lem: uuili din rehtkernon daz rihhi kistarkan.
app.rdg: He wants to secure the realm for the righteous

app.lem: pidiu scal imo helfan der himiles kiuualtit.
app.rdg: He who rules in heaven shall help him with this.

app.lem: der antichristo stet pi demo altfiante,
app.rdg: The antichrist stands with the ancient foe,

app.lem: stet pi Satanase, der inan uarsenkan scal.
app.rdg: Stands with Satan, who wants to destroy him [Elijah]:

app.lem: pidiu scal er in deru uuicsteti uuunt pivallan
app.rdg: But he [the antichrist] will fall wounded on this battlefield,

app.lem: enti in demo sinde sigalos uuerdan.
app.rdg: And in this way be without victory.

app.lem: Doh uuanit des uilo gotmanno,
app.rdg: Yet many men of God believe

app.lem: daz Elias in demo uuige aruuartit uuerde.
app.rdg: That Elijah will be wounded in the battle.

app.lem: so daz Eliases pluot in erda kitriufit,
app.rdg: So when Elijah’s blood drips on the earth,

app.lem: so inprinnant die perga, poum ni kistentit
app.rdg: The mountains catch fire and no single tree on earth

app.lem: enihc in erdu, aha artruknent,
app.rdg: remains standing, all waters dry up,

app.lem: muor uarsuuilhit sih, suilizot lougiu der himil,
app.rdg: The moor swallows itself, the heaven perishes in flames,

app.lem: mano uallit, prinnit mittilagart,
app.rdg:
The moon falls, Middle Earth burns.
“mittilagart” could also be translated as “Midgard”, (although the phrase "middle earth" is now well known to readers of Tolkein) which was the name of the human realm in Norse and Germanic myth. It is an interesting example of the mixing of pagan cosmological models with Christian apocalyptic narrative.

app.lem: sten ni kistentit eikin in erdu, uerit denne tuatago in lant,
app.rdg: Stones do not stand fast by their owners on earth, and then judgement day comes upon the land,

app.lem: uerit mit diu uuiru uiriho uuison.
app.rdg: Comes with fire to afflict the people:

app.lem: Dar ni mac denne mak helfan uora demo muspille.
app.rdg:
No kinsman can help the other in the face of the Muspilli.
The exact translation and etymology of “muspille” is unclear. Later Nordic sources suggest that it roughly means “destruction of the world by fire”.

app.lem: denne daz preita uuasal allaz uarprennit
app.rdg: And when the whole circle of the world burns,

app.lem: enti uuir enti luft iz allaz arfurpit,
app.rdg: and a storm of fire and air annihilates everything,

app.lem: uuar ist denne diu marha, dar man dar eo mit sinen magon piehc?
app.rdg: Where is then the homeland, for which one before had fought together with one’s kinsmen?

app.lem: Diu marha ist farprunnan, diu sela stet piduungan,
app.rdg: The homeland is burned, the soul stands defeated,

app.lem: ni uueiz mit uuiu puaze: sar verit si za uuize.
app.rdg: Not knowing how to atone: soon she will face punishment.

app.lem: Pidiu ist demo manne so guot, denner ze demo mahale quimit,
app.rdg: Therefore it is good for a man, when he comes to the tribunal,

app.lem: daz er rahono uueliha rehto arteile.
app.rdg: To have always delivered rightful judgements.

app.lem: Denne ni darf er sorgen, denne er ze deru suonu quimit.
app.rdg: Then he needs not to worry when he faces this trial.

app.lem: ni uueiz der uuenago man uuielihan uuartil er habet,
app.rdg: A weak person does not know what sentence awaits him,

app.lem: denner mit den miaton marrit daz rehta,
app.rdg: when he breaks the law with bribery,

app.lem: daz der tiuual dar pi kitarnit stentit.
app.rdg: And that the devil hides close to him,

app.lem: der hapet in ruouu rahono uueliha,
app.rdg: and quietly takes into account every evil deed

app.lem: daz der man er enti sid upiles kifrumita,
app.rdg: that this person has done and will do,

app.lem: daz er iz allaz kisaget, denne er ze deru suono quimit.
app.rdg: In order to report it all when he [the man] faces the trial.

app.lem: Ni scolta manno nohhein miatun intfahan.
app.rdg: Therefore, nobody should ever accept bribes.

app.lem: So daz himilisca horn kilutit uuirdit
app.rdg: When the heavenly horn is blown

app.lem: enti sih der suanari ana den sind arheuit,
app.rdg: And the judge, who shall judge the dead

app.lem: der da suannan scal toten enti lepenten,
app.rdg: and the living, will start his journey,

app.lem: denne heuit sih mit imo herio meista.
app.rdg: the largest host will rise together with him.

app.lem: daz ist allaz so pald, daz imo nioman kipagan ni mak.
app.rdg: This [host] is so brave that no one can stand up against it.

app.lem: Denne uerit er ze deru mahalsteti, deru dar kimarchot ist,
app.rdg: Then he will go to the judgement place, which is staked out,

app.lem: dar uuirdit diu suona, dia man dar io sageta.
app.rdg: That is where the trial will take place as it has been proclaimed.

app.lem: Denne uarant engila uper dio marha,
app.rdg: Angels will then travel over the land,

app.lem: uuechant deota, uuissant ze dinge.
app.rdg: wake the dead, call them to the judgement.

app.lem: denne scal manno gilih fona deru moltu arsten,
app.rdg: Then everybody will resurrect from the dust,

app.lem: Lossan si ar dero leuuo vazzon, scal imo auar sin lip piqueman,
app.rdg: Release himself from the burden of the grave: he shall regain his body,

app.lem: daz er sin reht allaz kirahhn muozzi
app.rdg: So that he can fairly answer for everything

app.lem: enti imo after sinen tatin arteilit uuerde.
app.rdg: And be judged for his deeds.

app.lem: Denne der gisizzit, der dâr suonnan scal
app.rdg: Then he sits down, the one who shall try in court

app.lem: enti arteillan scal toten enti quekkhen,
app.rdg: And pass judgement over the dead and the living;

app.lem: denne stet dar umpi engilo menigi,
app.rdg: The host of angels surrounds him,

app.lem: guotero gomono: gart ist so mihhil,
app.rdg: and [many] good men: The place [of judgement] is large,

app.lem: dara quimit ze deu rihtungu so uilo, dia dar ar resti arstent
app.rdg: And so many who have arisen from their rest come to the trial.

app.lem: so dar manno nohhein uuiht pimidan ni mak,
app.rdg: Nobody can hide anything there,

app.lem: dar scal denne hant sprehhan, houpit sagen,
app.rdg: Or else the hand will speak, the head will talk,

app.lem: allero lido uuelihc unzi in den luzigun uinger,
app.rdg: Every limb down to the smallest finger,

app.lem: uuaz er untar mannun mordes kifrumita.
app.rdg: What murder it has committed amongst men.

app.lem: Dar ni ist eo so listic man, der dar iouuiht arliugan megi,
app.rdg: Therefore nobody is cunning enough to be able to tell a lie there

app.lem: daz er kitarnan megi tato dehheina,
app.rdg: Or to hide any deed:

app.lem: niz al fora demo khuninge kichundit uuerde,
app.rdg: It will still be revealed in front of the king

app.lem: uzzan er iz mit alamusanu furimegi
app.rdg: unless he can compensate for it with alms [he has given],

app.lem: enti mit fastun dio uirina kipuazti.
app.rdg: And has atoned for the crimes with fasting.

app.lem: Denne der paldet, der gipuazzit hapet, denner ze deru suonu quimit.
app.rdg: Therefore he, who has atoned, needs not to worry when he comes to this judgement.

app.lem: uuirdit denne furi kitragan daz frono chruci,
app.rdg: Then the noble cross will be carried forward,

app.lem: dar der heligo Christ ana arhangan uuard,
app.rdg: Upon which the holy Christ was crucified,

app.lem: denne augit er dio masun, dio er in deru menniski anfenc,
app.rdg: And he will show the wounds that he received as a man,

app.lem: duruh desse mancunnes minna f[ardoleta]...
app.rdg: That he had obtained for his love of mankind.
